webTitle: The Jamaicanisation of the eurozone | Mark Weisbrot

fields.standfirst: By imposing budget cuts and austerity, the ECB is condemning countries like Greece and Spain to an economic twilight zone
fields.body:
Jamaica, an English-speaking Caribbean island nation of 2.9 million people, may seem worlds away from Europe. The country's income per person of $9,000 ranks it 88th in the world, as compared to the eurozone countries, which are three or four times richer. But they face a common problem, and although none of the eurozone countries is likely to become as poor as Jamaica is today, they could easily – going forward – mimic the dismal economic performance that Jamaica has seen over the past 20 years.

Jamaica has the world's highest public debt burden: interest payments on the government's debt account for 10% of the country's national income. (For comparison, Greece – with the worst debt burden in Europe – is paying 6.8% of GDP in interest.) This leaves little room for public investment in infrastructure, or improving education or healthcare. Partly as a result of this debt trap, Jamaica's income per person has grown by just 0.7% annually over the past 20 years.

Two years ago, Jamaica reached an agreement with its creditors, brokered by the IMF, that restructured its debt. Interest payments were lowered, and some principal payments were pushed forward. But the debt burden remained unsustainable. The IMF now projects that Jamaica's debt will reach 153% of GDP in just three years.

Sound familiar? That is what happened to Greece just four months ago. The Greek government reached an agreement with the European authorities (the "Troika" of the European Central Bank or ECB, the European Commission, and the IMF) that reduced its debt. Unlike in Jamaica, the private investors holding Greek debt took a "haircut", losing about half of the principal.

But still, it wasn't enough. Before the ink was dry on the deal, an IMF estimate of a "pessimistic scenario" going forward showed Greek debt reaching more than 160% of GDP by 2020. Since the IMF's projections for Greece over the past few years have proved enormously over-optimistic, and with Europe sliding further into recession, the pessimistic scenario is the more likely one. This means that even if Greek voters end up with a government that accepts the agreement – by no means guaranteed – it is likely that their economy will limp along from one crisis to the next until there is another restructuring, or a chaotic default.

In both Greece and Jamaica, the problem is not just the debt itself; even more, it is the policies that the creditors have attached to further lending. In Greece, this is extreme: the Troika insisted on Greece cutting 8.6% of GDP from its fiscal deficit over the past two years – the equivalent of the United States wiping out its entire federal budget deficit of $1.3tn. Naturally, the economy went into a tailspin. In Jamaica also, the IMF attached conditions during the 2008-2009 economic crisis that worsened the country's downturn.

Europe's problem with harmful policies attached to official lending is not limited to Greece. Dow Jones' recent headline tells the sad story of Portugal in a sentence: "EU: Portugal Will Need More Austerity To Meet Deficit Targets." Yes, the European Commission wants Portugal to make even bigger budget cuts because the ones they already made have shrunk the economy so much that they won't make their target deficit-to-GDP ratio. The economy is projected to shrink by a painful 3.3% this year, and official unemployment has risen from 12.9% last year, to 15.3% this. Ireland is in recession, yet it, too, is engaging in big budget tightening.

Spain hasn't yet had to borrow from the Troika, but has followed the same policies. With more than half of its youth languishing in unemployment, Spain's fiscal tightening – according to the government's projections – will carve 2.6% out of its economic growth this year.

Of course, there are many important differences between the situation of the eurozone countries and Jamaica, and among the eurozone countries themselves. Jamaica needs debt cancellation; some of the eurozone countries in trouble – for example, Spain – would have a sustainable debt burden if the ECB would simply intervene in the sovereign bond markets and guarantee a low interest rate on their bonds. And the ECB, as the issuer of a hard currency in a monetary area with no serious inflationary threat, has a lot of room to do whatever is necessary to make sure that all of the eurozone countries have low borrowing costs and therefore sustainable debt.

But the ECB has refused to use its powers to put an end to the sovereign debt crisis, preferring instead – hand-in-hand with the rest of the Troika – to exploit it in order to force unpopular political changes in eurozone countries, especially the weaker ones. In so doing, they are condemning these countries to the long-term stagnation of high unemployment and slow growth that Jamaica has suffered for the past two decades. Although the human costs are much higher in a developing country such as Jamaica, this still entails a huge amount of unnecessary suffering on both sides of the ocean.

webTitle: UK 'may never fully recover' if Greece exits euro

fields.bodyText: A Greek exit from the single currency threatens to plunge Britain into a second recession equal in ferocity to the record postwar slump of 2008-09, according to the expert responsible for the government's economic forecasting. Robert Chote, chair of the Office for Budget Responsibility, who was speaking to the Guardian as world financial markets staggered to the end of a week that rekindled memories of the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008, warned that there was risk that a fresh downturn would do irreparable damage to the UK. Britain has made up less than half the ground lost when output plunged by more than 7% in 2008-09, and Chote said there was a risk that "you go down and you never quite get back up to where you started". In a separate exclusive interview, Alexis Tsipras, the increasingly powerful 37-year-old Greek politician now regarded by many as holding the future of the euro in his hands, told the Guardian that he was determined "to stop the experiment" with austerity policies imposed by Germany. He described the tax increases and spending cuts as a "crime against the Greek people". The leader of the Syriza party, whose success in last month's general election has led to political paralysis in Athens and a second general election, said he wanted Greece to stay in the euro, but was fighting capitalism. "On the one side there are workers and a majority of people, and on the other are global capitalists, bankers, profiteers on stock exchanges, the big funds. It's a war between peoples and capitalism ... it is the international financial system, and more especially banks, that are gaining most". The head of the UK's OBR said the deepening crisis in the eurozone could force him to tear up his forecasts, made only two months ago, that Britain would post modest growth of 0.8% this year. "The concern is that you end up with an outcome in the eurozone that creates the same sort of structural difficulties in the financial system and in the economy that we saw in the past recession, and that has consequences both for hitting economic activity in the economy, but also its underlying potential," said Chote. With economic output in the UK still 4% below its peak level when the recession began in early 2008, the prime minister and the governor of the Bank of England, Sir Mervyn King, have expressed concern in recent days about the vulnerability of Britain to the eurozone. Chote said he was particularly concerned about the possibility that a second deep recession would leave permanent scars. "That means not just that the economy weakens and then strengthens again – it goes into a hole and comes out – but that you go down and you never quite get back up to where you started." Shares in London closed down for a third week, with the jittery mood in financial markets pushing the FTSE 100 below 5,400 for the first time this year. German and French stock markets were also depressed, with even the much-anticipated stock market debut of Facebook in New York failing to lift spirits. Greece's caretaker prime minister, Panagiotis Pikramenos, said the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, had suggested in a phone call to the Greek president, Karolos Papoulias, on Friday that Greece hold a referendum on its continued membership of the single currency alongside next month's elections, in an apparent attempt to encourage voters to back mainstream parties who support the current austerity programme. The German government said that no suggestion of the kind had been made. But the Greek government was insistent, and said that Pikramenos had rejected the suggestion because he does not have the power to call a referendum. Merkel's finance minister, Wolfgang Schäuble, said the eurozone crisis could last two more years, while financial market speculation that Greece's days in the euro were numbered cast a shadow over the annual gathering of leaders of the G8 western industrial nations at Camp David. Canada's prime minister, Stephen Harper, voiced his frustration at Europe's leaders, demanding tough action to tackle the crisis. In Brussels, the European commission denied comments by Europe's trade minister, Karel de Gucht, that preparations were being made for Greece's departure from the single currency. Meanwhile, analysts at Deutsche Bank predicted that the weak state of Ireland's banks could result in the former Celtic tiger requiring a second bailout, and in Spain there were reports that the government would call in Goldman Sachs to help sort out its banks after 16 suffered credit downgrades on Thursday. In an echo of the months leading up to the Lehmans collapse, Mike Smith, chief executive of Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, said the turmoil in the eurozone meant Australian banks were being frozen out of money markets when seeking funds. Chote said there were so many uncertainties around what might happen with Greece and the eurozone that trying to produce firm predictions was not "particularly helpful". But the OBR has tried to quantify the impact of a disorderly sovereign debt restructuring in the eurozone on Britain – and the figures make grim reading. Britain would be plunged into recession for two years, according to the OBR analysis, published in its most recent economic and fiscal outlook report. There would also be deflation and unemployment would reach almost 11% by 2013-14, with debt subsequently reaching more than 90% of GDP. Chote said these projections were of limited value because the eurozone crisis could develop in so many different ways. "For example, one issue would be, do difficulties in the eurozone make it cheaper or more expensive for the UK government to borrow?" he said. "If it makes investors more nervous about risk in general, it might make it more expensive. If they see the UK as more of a safe haven, it might make it less expensive."

webTitle: Santander UK funds ringfenced under FSA order

fields.standfirst: Bank needs regulator's permission to transfer any cash back to its Spanish parent company
fields.body:
Santander UK has been prevented from transferring any cash back to its Spanish parent company since December under a voluntary agreement with the Financial Services Authority.

The so-called "regulatory order" means that Santander UK needs the regulator's permission to transfer cash, underlining Santander UK's claim that its assets are ringfenced from its parent company. Concerns about the health of Spain's banks were growing following the mass downgrade by Moody's late on Thursday.

Steve Pateman, head of Santander UK's high-street banking operation, told the Guardian that the UK business had not paid a dividend to its parent company since the first half of 2011 and emphasised the financial strength of the UK business.

The FSA confirmed that the restriction was in place. "With the full co-operation of Santander UK, the FSA has in place arrangements that require the FSA to give permission to any transfer of funds out of the UK by Santander UK."

Santander's shares rose on Friday despite the mass downgrades, as the Madrid stock market regained its composure after Thursday's rout, which had been prompted by a dramatic fall in the shares of bailed-out Bankia.

The Madrid stock market gained 0.2% even after the Bank of Spain revealed that bad loans in Spain's banks, which have been hit by a bursting of the property bubble, have reached their highest levels in 18 years.

The Spanish government is to call in Goldman Sachs to make an independent valuation of Bankia, the country's fourth-largest lender, whose shares bounced back 23.5% on Friday, compensating for the 14% drop on Thursday, following reports – which were denied – of withdrawals from the bank.

The admission by Spain's central bank that bad loans had reached their highest in 18 years in March put further pressure on a country that is already at the centre of concerns about the long-term viability of the eurozone. With 8.37% of outstanding loans now deemed bad, the government was under pressure to hasten the work of independent auditors who are to review the value of Spanish bank assets.

The independent auditors will be named on Monday and asked to deliver the results of rapid stress tests within a month. A fuller study will be published in two or three months.

The moves come as Spain tries to persuade markets that its banks are not hiding toxic real estate assets left over from the 2008 housing bust.

"We think the stress tests will clarify everything," a senior government source said. "We will be totally transparent about what these valuers do."

While shares in Spanish banks were firmer, UK banks were hit hard amid the continued anxiety about the eurozone's future.

Bailed-out Lloyds Banking Group and Royal Bank of Scotland were the biggest fallers in the FTSE 100, losing 6% and 5% respectively on a day when the FTSE 100 index lost 1.3% of its value.

Spain partly nationalised Bankia last week because of the weight of junk real estate assets on its books.

Senior government sources said Bankia would next week present a plan to clean up its balance sheet, with many observers expecting it to sell off its shares in major companies such as insurance provider Mapfre.

The Expansión newspaper reported that Bankia's financial hole may reach €8bn (£6.4bn) on top of the €10bn that it must set aside to cover potential real estate losses.

The government has said it wants help from Europe to see out the coming storm – probably in the form of bond purchases by the European Central Bank - though it is against direct intervention.

webTitle: No Facebook fillip at end of worst week since August

fields.standfirst: Facebook IPO unable to lift spirits as London closes on week that £80bn is wiped off FTSE 100 amid eurozone crisis woes
fields.body:
Leading shares suffered their worst week since August as the eurozone crisis escalated, with growing talk that Greece could leave the single currency and Spain could come back into the line of fire.

As leaders of the G8 industrial nations met to discuss the situation, the FTSE 100 fell 70.76 points to 5267.62, its fifth day of losses and its worst level since 25 November last year.

Over the week the index lost 308 points, with just short of £80bn wiped off the value of Britain's top companies. News that Greece would call a new election after failing to form a government added more uncertainty to a volatile situation, with anti-austerity party Syriza threatening to tear up the country's bailout agreement. June's vote is now widely seen as a referendum on euro membership.

Meanwhile, there were more signs of contagion in the rest of the eurozone, with rating agency Moody's downgrading 16 Spanish banks amid concerns about debt levels.

So financial shares fell sharply lower, on concern about their exposure to Spain and the rest of the eurozone, with Lloyds Banking Group losing 1.7p to 25.95p, Royal Bank of Scotland falling 1.07p to 19.99p and Barclays closing 5.8p lower at 176.1p.

Talk that China might offer support to the eurozone by buying government bonds, and suggestions of a ban on short selling European shares, provided a minor fillip, but this soon wore off.

Nor did shares receive much benefit from the much hyped – but delayed – Facebook flotation, with Wall Street down around 40 points by the time London closed.

Mining shares subsided after data showed that house prices in China fell 1.2% in April, the second monthly decline in a row. Goldman Sachs also downgraded its growth forecast for second-quarter GDP in China – a big consumer of commodities – from 8.5% to 7.9%. Xstrata dropped 41.5p to 914.7p and Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation fell 16p to 457.9p. But Mexican precious metals miner Fresnillo added 28p to £13.58 after a positive annual meeting statement.

The problems at hedge fund group Man continued after Standard & Poor's moved its outlook from stable to negative. It said there was a one-in-three probability of a downgrade if its weak performance, particularly at its AHL fund, and client outflows continued. Meanwhile, Numis repeated its sell advice, with analyst David McCann saying the business was worth no more than its liquidation value, which it put at between 50p and 75p a share. He also dismissed recent talk that Man could find itself as a bid target. Man closed 3.25p lower at 75.3p.

ITV dipped 3.05p to 78.85p after analysts at HSBC put an underweight rating on the broadcaster, although the bank raised its price target from 74p to 83p.

BT bucked the trend, adding 1.5p to 204p following an upgrade from analysts at Berenberg, who raised their rating from hold to buy and their price target from 220p to 245p. The bank said: "We believe that BT will beat expectations by more than 2%. Against a backdrop of most other incumbent operators facing increasing operational pressure and threats to forecasts, we believe this will continue to make BT a safe haven."

Among the mid-caps, the London Stock Exchange added 27.5p to 992p after announcing a 30% rise in full-year profits. In a buy note, James Hamilton at Numis said: "[This was a] strong result from the LSE, 6% ahead of consensus excluding exceptional gains. With the benefits of the acquisitions largely still to flow through the profit and loss account, we believe the LSE offers good value at less than 10 times historic earnings."

Invensys slipped 0.6p to 211p but outperformed the market after analysts at UBS issued a buy note on the engineering group and raised their price target from 225p to 235p after Thursday's final results. Invensys has been the subject of recent bid speculation, with China's CSR, Siemens, ABB and General Electric all mentioned as possible predators. But UBS said: "We are not believers in M&A rhetoric. While the probability of an offer seems to have risen (given recent press reports), we wouldn't count on it."

Lamprell continued its decline, down 7.5p to 121p. The oil services group issued a surprise profit warning on Wednesday, just two weeks after two directors sold shares. On Friday HSBC cut its target price from 440p to 215p and said: "Potential return supports an overweight rating but we don't see a quick recovery."

webTitle: JD Wetherspoon boss buys £2.5m of shares

fields.standfirst: Tim Martin takes his holding to 26.6% just weeks after pub chain reveals its tax bill would increase by £50m
fields.body:
Tim Martin, chairman and founder of pub chain JD Wetherspoon, has bought nearly £2.5m-worth of shares in the company. The flamboyant boss bought 657,000 shares for 377p each on Thursday, taking his holding in the group to 26.6%.

It comes just weeks after the business, which has 850 pubs across the country, revealed its tax bill would jump £50m, or 11%, this year owing to the 20% VAT level, new fruit machine levies and late-night taxes.

Martin warned this month the high taxes, which he has been railing against for several years, would slow down the company's expansion plans.

He said: "We've reached a crisis point and unless the issue of taxation in pubs is addressed, it will continue to lead to more pubs shutting and creating further unemployment."

Closing at 377p on Friday, the shares are currently trading at a three-year low.

But it would seem Martin, worth an estimated £750m, believes there is promise in the business.

webTitle: Unions fear Tesco move into post offices

fields.standfirst: Through its One Stop convenience chain, the UK's biggest retailer has been taking part in the 'Post Office Local' pilot
fields.body:
Tesco could become a major player in a restructured Post Office – handing out pensions and benefit payments – as a government sponsored cost-cutting drive looks to replace traditional counters with a cheaper service offered at the checkouts of convenience stores.

Through its One Stop convenience chain, the UK's biggest retailer has been taking part in the Post Office Local pilot which sees traditional fortress counters replaced by a hybrid till service where staff in shops and petrol stations juggle mail and bill payments alongside baskets of groceries.

Postal unions are worried after comments made by the Post Office chief executive, Paula Vennells, at last week's Commons business select committee suggested One Stop was keen to offer the service in all 600 of its stores.

She told MPs: "I was in a meeting last week with the minister, so this was said in front of the postal affairs minister [Norman Lamb], where one of the operators who is running 25 of these new locals asked if they could have one in every one of the 600 stores they have."

Industry experts said the executive was referring to One Stop as it is the only multiple operating more than 20 Locals at present. There are 177 Locals with 28 run by One Stop. Other convenience chains involved include the Co-op, Spar and Martin McColl.

Vennells is understood to have been referring to a conversation at a round-table event hosted by Lamb to discuss the Post Office's "network strategy".

To become a Local a subpostmaster must give up an annual fixed payment from the Post Office and instead work on a commission basis. To encourage them to take the leap the Post Office is offering a payment of up to £10,000 for store refurbishments. On that basis One Stop, which was acquired by Tesco in 2002 as part of its £377m acquisition of T&S Stores, would have been entitled to up to £280,000 to revamp its 28 stores.

Vennells told the committee that retailers liked the new Local model because it increased staff productivity – specialist staff are no longer required to stay behind the separate counter and can serve shoppers – and boosted sales by an average of 9%. Industry sources suggested other retailers were less enthusiastic about adopting the Local model but would feel pressured to do so if the alternative was the business being handed to One Stop.

The Post Office was previously part of Royal Mail Group but became independent last month when the government created separate companies. Ministers are priming the Royal Mail for sale – either through a stock market flotation, or a private sale – but hope the Post Office will eventually be mutualised. The most recent annual report shows the Post Office making an operating profit of £21m on sales of £776m. It receives an annual government subsidy of £150m.

George Thomson, from the National Federation of SubPostmasters, said it would oppose any Post Office tie-up with Tesco: "I'd warn the Post Office they have to be very careful that they don't get in bed with Tesco because Tesco are seen as actually damaging local retail and damaging local high streets."

Vennells told the committee the Post Office network was already a "mixed economy" with independent and multiple retailers working side by side. WH Smith, for example, has 70 franchises. A Post Office spokesman said: "We have no plans to roll out additional post office branches into One Stop shops." One Stop also denied that a rollout to all of its 613 shops was on the cards: "Customers like the convenience of post office services in One Stop shops, but we do not have plans or aspirations to roll out services across all our stores," said a spokesman.

Earlier this year the government earmarked £1.3bn to begin modernising the Post Office network. The money is being targeted at half its 11,800 branches with Post Office bosses aiming for 2,000 "locals" and 4,000 so-called "main" post offices. Those running these larger outlets are entitled to grants of up to £45,000 for refurbishments but must also give up the fixed pay element of their income. The changes are designed to reduce the Post Office's £450m annual bill for sub-postmaster remuneration.

The Local model has come under fire from watchdog Consumer Focus which, in a recent report, found several problems with the new services, including basic errors such as second-class postage being sold correctly only one in five times. Large or heavy parcels were refused in a quarter of cases and special delivery was mis-sold in a third of cases.

webTitle: Bank of England's Posen to step down in the summer

fields.standfirst: Sir Mervyn King, the bank's governor, said Posen had made an 'outstanding contribution' during his three years on the MPC
fields.body:
Adam Posen, the Bank of England arch-dove, is to step down from the Bank's interest rate setting committee at the end of the summer, undermining hopes of further monetary easing to bolster the ailing UK economy.

Posen has refused to apply for a second term on the monetary policy committee after accepting a job as boss of the US economic thinktank, the Peterson Institute.

For a long time he was a lone voice on the committee arguing for a boost to the £200bn intervention made in the immediate aftermath of the Lehman's collapse in 2008.

The prospect of further quantitative easing this year appeared to be strong after the UK fell into a second recession in three years and indicators showed business confidence and household finances on the decline.

Posen, a US academic, voted against an increase in the £325bn in bond purchases by the Bank of England at the MPC's last meeting after he and his eight colleagues were spooked by a rise in inflation during March and some business surveys that showed a more upbeat picture than official data.

But he has since indicated that he would renew his call to print more electronic money after a series of troubling forecasts.

The Treasury, which appoints external members to the committee, said it would advertise shortly for a role that is open to all senior economists.

The MPC's last appointment was Goldman Sachs economist Ben Broadbent, who arrived last summer. The Treasury was criticised at the time for failing to find a woman candidate. The committee, which was founded in 1997 by former chancellor Gordon Brown as an independent bulwark against the interest rate setting whims of the Treasury, always had at least one woman until the departure of Kate Barker in 2010.

Sir Mervyn King, the bank's governor, said Posen had made an "outstanding contribution" during his three years on the MPC and wished him well in his new role.

But during most of that time the two men have been at loggerheads over how to adjust monetary policy at a time of government cuts, tax rises and an unstable situation in the eurozone.

Posen made it clear in a series of speeches – backed up by his voting record on the MPC – that it should move more quickly to support the economy.

While he never accused King by name, he believed the governor and his supporters underestimated the slow pace of recovery and the negative effect of the government's policies on investment and spending.

It was the third time the governor was accused of being slow to react to events, after he waited until the last moment to rescue Northern Rock, triggering the first bank run in more than 100 years. King was also accused by former MPC member David Blanchflower of being slow to cut interest rates in 2008 when the Lehman's crisis was looming.

Jonathan Portes, head of the National Institute of Economic and Social Research, said Posen would be much missed.

"He has been a sane and sensible voice on the MPC and his interpretation of the economy has proved to be justified."

Posen said: "I am proud of the work we have done trying to understand and stabilise UK economic performance in the aftermath of the global crisis. I also am sincerely grateful to the many people from all areas of the United Kingdom who engaged with me openly and frankly during my travels for the MPC."

webTitle: FTSE 100 suffers worst week since August with £80bn wiped off value of UK's top companies

fields.standfirst: Investors fear Greek eurozone exit after new elections called, while Spanish banks under pressure
fields.body:
Leading shares suffered their worst week since August last year as the eurozone crisis escalated, with growing talk that Greece could leave the single currency and Spain coming back into the firing line.

As leaders of the G8 industrial nations met to discuss the situation, the FTSE 100 fell 70.76 points to 5267.62, its fifth day of losses and its worst level since 25 November last year.

Over the week the leading index lost 308 points, with just short of £80bn wiped off the value of Britain's top companies according to FTSE Group. News that Greece would call a new election after failing to form a government added more uncertainty to an already volatile situation, with anti-austerity party Syriza threatening to tear up the country's bailout agreement. June's vote is now widely seen as a referendum on euro membership. Meanwhile there were more signs of contagion in the rest of the eurozone, with ratings agency Moody's downgrading 16 Spanish banks amid concerns about the country's debt levels.

So financial shares fell sharply lower, on concern about their exposure to Spain and the rest of the eurozone, with Lloyds Banking Group losing 1.7p to 25.95p, Royal Bank of Scotland falling 1.07p to 19.99p and Barclays closing 5.8p lower at 176.1p.

Talk that China might offer support to the eurozone by buying government bonds, and suggestions of a ban on short selling European shares, provided a minor fillip during the day, but this soon wore off.

Nor did shares receive much benefit from the much-hyped - but delayed - Facebook flotation, with Wall Street down around 40 points by the time London closed.

Mining shares subsided after data showed house prices in China fell 1.2% in April, the second monthly decline in a row. Goldman Sachs also downgraded its growth forecast for second quarter GDP in China - a key consumer of commodities - from 8.5% to 7.9%. Xstrata dropped 41.5p to 914.7p and Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation fell 16p to 457.9p. But Mexican precious metals miner Fresnillo added 28p to £13.58 after a positive annual meeting statement.

The problems at hedge fund group Man continued after Standard & Poor's moved its outlook from stable to negative. It said there was a one in three probability of a downgrade if its weak performance, particularly at its key AHL fund, and client outflows continued. Man closed 3.25p lower at 75.3p. Peter Lenardos at RBC Capital Markets said:

S&P states that the stable outlook could be restored if Man returns to sustained net sales, investment performance is consistently strong and supportive of enhanced future fund inflows, and management acts in a way that adequately balances the priorities of bondholders and shareholders. Our forecasts do not envision either sustained net sales or "consistently strong" investment performance.
We expect Man Group's share price volatility to persist. We continue to believe that news flow, AHL performance and share price trends could present attractive short-term trading opportunities.

Meanwhile Numis repeated its sell advice, with analyst David McCann saying the business was worth no more than its liquidation value, which it put at between 50p and 75p a share. He also dismissed recent talk that Man could find itself as a bid target:

Whilst it is dangerous to completely rule the possibility out, our feeling is that the possibility of being acquired is remote, unless it were to trade below liquidation value. Anyone acquiring Man today has exactly the same problem as shareholders - no one really knows with any degree of certainty how AHL will perform and therefore what the largest part of the group is worth. Also, Man has been considered by many to have been in "stressed" share price territory on a number of occasions over the last five years and has often been linked with an "imminent" approach. If anyone was really interested, surely they would have played their hand by now.

ITV dipped 3.05p to 78.85p after analysts at HSBC put an underweight rating on the broadcaster, although the bank raised its price target from 74p to 83p:

ITV has short-term momentum but there are long-term concerns. Estimate revisions have been driven mainly by non-core operations and other one-offs. Our leading indicators predicted the UK TV advertising spend decline in the second half of 2011 and remain negative; each 1% decline in advertising takes around 5% off earnings per share.

But BT bucked the trend, adding 1.5p to 204p following an upgrade from analysts at Berenberg, who raised their rating from hold to buy and their price target from 220p to 245p. The bank said:

Having revisited our cost analysis for BT, we conclude that consensus estimates for March 2013 are too low and we believe that BT will beat expectations by more than 2%. Against a backdrop of most other incumbent operators facing increasing operational pressure and threats to forecasts, we believe this will continue to make BT a safe haven.

Among the mid-caps, the London Stock Exchange added 27.5p to 992p after it announced a 30% rise in full year profits. In a buy note James Hamilton at Numis said:

[This was a] strong result from the LSE, 6% ahead of consensus excluding exceptional gains. With the benefits of the acquisitions largely still to flow through the profit and loss account, we believe the LSE offers good value at less than 10 times historic earnings.

Invensys slipped 0.6p to 211p but outperformed the market after analysts at UBS issued a buy note on the engineering group and raised their price target from 225p to 235p following Thursday's final results. They said:

[The] results were mixed. Invensys operations management margins were on the weak side even excluding problematic nuclear contracts and if we adjust for issues in Australia, rail growth was still non-existent. However, as with any Invensys results day, we were braced for worse. There were in fact a lot of positives too – operations management order book coverage, the reiteration of 15%-17% medium term rail margins and the improved cash flow.

Invensys has been the subject of bid speculation in recent weeks, with China's CSR, Siemens, ABB and General Electric all mentioned as possible predators. But UBS said:

We are not believers in M&A rhetoric. While the probability of an offer appears to have risen (given recent press reports) we would not count on it.

But Lamprell continued its decline, down 7.5p to 121p. The oil services group issued a surprise profit warning on Wednesday, just two weeks after two directors sold shares. Yesterday HSBC cut its target price from 440p to 215p and said:

Potential return supports an overweight rating but we don't see a quick recovery.

Finally Icap slipped 3.6p to 338.4p after the interdealer broker agreed to buy the junior stock exchange run by Plus Markets for a nominal £1. Plus, whose quoted companies include Arsenal, Stieg Larsson publisher Quercus and brewer Adnams, said earlier in the week it would close down its exchange operation after failing to find a buyer, but subsequently it confirmed reports that Icap was interested in the business.

webTitle: Selling porkies: boost for UK exports as Chinese pig out

fields.standfirst: Much of the exported pork will be offal, tripe, trotters, ears and other parts of the so called "fifth quarter" – the parts Brits tend to turn their nose up at, but the Chinese savour
fields.body:
Britons may love their bacon sandwiches, but the parts of the pig that most of us refuse to eat are to form the main dish in a £50m pork export deal with China.

The first consignment is ready to be dispatched by Tulip, the UK's biggest producer and the maker of Danepak bacon and Spam, following an agreement reached by UK agriculture minister Jim Paice during a trade mission to China.

Much of the exported pork will be offal, tripe, trotters, ears and other parts of the so- called "fifth quarter" – the parts Brits tend to turn their nose up at, but the Chinese savour.

It comes at the same time as farmers are stepping up exports of live breeding pigs to China, packing up to 900 at a time into a jumbo jet for a 12-hour non-stop flight. "They get full lie-down beds and water all the way," said pig breeder John Millard.

China is the world's biggest pork market, where the average person eats seven times as much of the meat as the average Briton. The trade breakthrough came after years of tortuous negotiations.

Paice told the Guardian at the animal husbandry show in Nanjing: "China is the most lucrative grocery market in the world and from fashion to food its rapidly expanding middle class has an appetite for western goods. In particular they are eating more meat, and our top quality producers have got huge opportunities to meet that demand and help our economic recovery."

The £50m deal compares with the €80-90m of pork Germany, Spain and France each send to China every year, and the €190m exported by Denmark.

A health protocol is in place and six UK plants have been approved to export quality pork cuts and fifth quarter to China.

Paice acknowledged that food safety was a bigger concern in China than elsewhere because "they've had more problems with food safety, which makes them extremely alert".

Paice said he now hoped to "get the ball rolling on beef and lamb". The problem is that European beef is still tainted by the BSE scares of the last decade.

China is the biggest market in the world for pork, with 50.7m tonnes consumed last year, according to Euromonitor International. John Millard, who runs JJ Genetics, a pig breeding business, said: "The Chinese eat more pork per capita than we do in the UK - it's their main meat. It always surprises me, given how poor many of them are."

The average Briton eats just 5.1kg of pork every year, compared with 37.8kg for the Chinese and 39.7 kg for Germans. Austrians are the biggest pork eaters in the world, with per capita consumption of 69.2kg, according to Euromonitor.

The deal also comes alongside growing exports to China of live British breeding pigs, in demand because they produce more lean meat more quickly than Chinese breeds, and are more fertile, according to farmers.

Last year Britain sent 3,000 live pigs to the country, a quarter of the total that China imported from around the world, according to Chris Jackson, export promoter at the British Pig Association. Boars sell for around £2,300 while sows go for £1,000 (farmers only need one boar to every 30 sows).

"They are making a fortune in China out of our pigs," said Millard. "Our pigs reduce their production costs by 35%."

The animals are prepared well for their flight by jumbo jet, he said. "We mix them up several weeks in advance so they don't fight" before they go on the plane, said Millard. None of his pigs has ever died in transit. Once breeding herds have been established in China, UK farmers will send bottles of semen keep the production line going – supplemented with a new batch of sows every other year.

Paice stressed that it was important for British businesses to retain the intellectual property rights.

Pork and live pig exports form part of the British food industry's drive to increase exports by 20% by 2020. Exports passed the £11m mark last year, according to the Food and Drink Federation.

The main breeds in the UK are large whites, Welsh landrace, Duroc and Pietrain. British sows produce more than 30 piglets a year, making them superior to animals from other countries. This is because farmers cross breed, say, a Welsh landrace with a large white, Millard said.

His pigs get slaughtered after 140-150 days - compared with 180-190 days for Chinese animals. The best pigs grow by 2kg a day towards the end, he said. "We have to be better because we are never going to be the cheapest."

• This article was amended on 21 May 2012 because it mistakenly gave an estimate for the amount of pork consumed by China last year as 50.7m kg; the correct figure is 50.7m tonnes.

webTitle: Robert Chote interview: 'I would not say in the past there's been rigging'

fields.standfirst: The chair of the Office for Budget Responsibility talks about the potential impact of the eurozone crisis on Britain, the reliability of economic forecasts, and the future role of the OBR
fields.body:
How bad is it going to get? As chair of the Office for Budget Responsibility, Robert Chote is the government's independent forecaster-in-chief and the man responsible for checking that George Osborne's budget figures add up. In a wide-ranging interview, Chote discussed the eurozone crisis and much else. Here are the main points.

• Chote said Greece leaving the euro could plunge Britain into a recession as bad as the last one, causing long-term damage to the economy. He stressed the difficulties of forecasting the economic consequences of a Greek exit, but acknowledged there was a danger "not just that the economy weakens and then strengthens again – ie, it goes into a hole and comes out – but that you go down and you never quite get back up to where you started".

• He said there was no evidence to show that cutting the 50p top rate of tax would promote growth. "We didn't feel that there was a strong enough evidence base to say our long-term or medium-term view of the economy is now more optimistic than it was beforehand as a result of that measure," he said.

• He said current spending on public sector pensions was sustainable in the long-term. The public finances as a whole would come under pressure in years to come, but the current pension regime was "not where the problem is coming from", he said.

• He claimed that the OBR was better at producing reliable forecasts than the Treasury used to be. "On public sector net borrowing … our errors are by and large smaller than the average errors were under the old regime [when the Treasury was in charge of producing forecasts for the government]," he said, producing figures showing that seven out of nine of the OBR's borrowing forecasts to date had been shown to be more accurate than Treasury ones were. He also produced figures showing that the OBR's growth forecasts were more reliable than average Treasury ones. Asked to explain why the OBR got it so wrong when it predicted reasonable growth in 2011 and 2012, he said higher-than-expected inflation, particularly from oil prices and food prices, was mainly to blame.

• He said the OBR should eventually be allowed to cost opposition policies. Under current legislation, it is banned from doing this. "Having independent rigorous analysis of all the political parties' policies is a good thing for them, it's a good thing for public debate, it's a good thing for democracy," he said. He also suggested that the current arrangement, which will allow Osborne to go into the election saying his plans have been approved by the OBR while Ed Balls won't be able to make the same claim, was potentially unfair.

The Office for Budget Responsibility, which was set up by Osborne after the election, sounds rather grand. But actually Chote's team is only about 20-strong and they operate from a rather poky office on Victoria Street. There are two-bit PR companies with larger headcounts and plusher premises.

Chote used to run the Institute for Fiscal Studies (employing about 50 people), and helped to establish it as the thinktank most trusted to impartially dissect government and opposition fiscal policies. "The fact that we looked at every party's plans, and normally said rude things about all of them, contributed to people's sense of our independence and our evenhandedness," he said. At the OBR he's more constrained because he's not allowed to comment on opposition policies, and whether they would be better than Osborne's. But in our interview he still managed to say at least two things likely to annoy Osborne (on the 50p top rate of tax, and public sector pensions), and one that will go down badly with Balls (on the reason for growth being much lower than expected). We spoke on Wednesday afternoon. Here's how it went.

Eurozone crisis

Q: At his press conference on Wednesday morning (pdf), Sir Mervyn King, the governor of the Bank of England, seemed to be saying – and I paraphrase – that it was so difficult trying to work out the impact of Greece leaving the eurozone that there was no point even trying. The OBR's position is different, because in your last economic and fiscal outlook (pdf), you did try to quantify it. Can you summarise what would happen?

A: Fundamentally the governor is right, and we've taken a similar approach in most of the recent forecasts that we've done. If you think about the bad outcome for the eurozone, there are so many different ways in which that could unfold that picking any one and working out the consequences of that for the economy and the public finances, and saying that that is representative of the bad outcome, isn't particularly helpful. There's an awful lot of uncertainty. For example, if Greece were to come out, does that make people more confident about the stability and cohesion of what is left? Or are people more nervous because they fear there will be contagion?

That said, you can say hopefully useful things about the sorts of ways in which greater difficulties in the eurozone might affect the UK and those that might be more or less important to the fiscal position, which is ultimately what we're interested in. The direct economic trade links between the UK and Greece are not that great. So it's less the direct effect than whether it leads to concerns about contagion and the stability of the system as a whole and, crucially, what impact that has on the smooth running of the financial system and the banking system.

The concern is that you end up with an outcome in the eurozone that creates the same sort of structural difficulties in the financial system and in the economy that we saw in the past recession, and that that has consquences both for hitting economic activity in the economy, but also its underlying potential. And it's the latter which has particular difficulties for the fiscal position, because it means not just that the economy weakens and then strengthens again – ie, it goes into a hole and comes out – but that you go down and you never quite get back up to where you started. And that has more lingering, long-term consequences for the public finances.

What we did in this report (pdf) was to say, for what it's worth, the OECD has come up with a story of how things might turn out. And we looked at that one.

And these figures [see page 177] suggest there would be negative growth for two years, deflation in 2013-14, unemployment higher than 10% and that the chancellor would miss his targets.

That's saying what would happen if this particular novelisation that the OECD came up with last year was to come up. But the point is that it could evolve in so many different ways. For example, one issue would be do difficulties in the eurozone make it cheaper or more expensive for the UK government to borrow? If it makes investors more nervous about risk in general, it might make it more expensive. If they see the UK as more of a safe haven, it might make it less expensive.

I suppose the question people really wanted answered is, how bad could it get? Can you answer that?

Well, no. The problem is that you would be coming up with one story and claiming it was representative. I think Mervyn's view is the right one, that you can't say there's a 10% chance that things will turn out like this. What you can say is let's take a way things could turn out and look what sort of effect it might have.

Reliability of OBR forecasts

That takes us on to forecasting. In your forecast evaluation report last year (pdf) you said one of the advantages of having the OBR produce forecasts instead of the Treasury was that people could be confident that "they are based on (inevitably fallible) professional judgment rather than politically motivated wishful thinking". How much evidence do you think there is that governments did rig their forecasts?

"Rig" is not a word I would use. The key point about the pre-OBR regime is that these were ministerial forecasts and ministers were entirely entitled to forecast whatever they wanted. It's not as if they were fiddling the numbers. They were their numbers. Certainly if you look at the period for 2002 onwards, the then government published forecasts for public finances that the IFS and the National Institute [of Economic and Social Research] and probably the IMF and the OECD all thought were probably too optimistic.

Another concern over that period was also the way in which the fiscal rules were written. There was a concern that it was easy to move the goalposts in such a way as to make them easier to hit. So I would not say in the past there's been "rigging". But I think there is a concern that governments of all stripes have an incentive to produce forecasts that do contain wishful thinking about the future. The creation of the OBR was, in part, a response to those sort of issues.

Is it your contention that having the OBR will create better forecasts? Or does it just create forecasts that are subject to the same degree of inaccuracy but people will …

Think they're inaccurate for the right reasons.

Exactly.

That's a good way of putting it. You might want to distinguish between the forecasts we make for the economy and the forecasts we make for the public finances, tax revenues and spending and budget deficits and things like that. For the economy, we have no privileged secret information about what's going on in the economy that everybody else in the world doesn't have. So there's no reason to believe that we should be better forecasters for the economy than anybody else is.

What we do have is additional information about what exactly is going on with public spending, what exactly is going on with tax receipts. We're able to have more discussions with people at HMRC about what is going on with tax receipts. So, for the fiscal forecasts, hopefully we are able to use that additional information.

When I posted a blog asking people to suggest questions I should ask you, I was surprised how negative the comments were. A lot of them [for example, Optymystic, manzo and hrwaldram] focused on accuracy, with people saying your forecasts are no better, or if anything worse, than the Treasury ones were. On the key indicators, are you doing better than the Treasury or are you doing worse?

On the fiscal numbers, on public sector net borrowing (PSNB), for what it is worth – and we've only got a couple of years to go on – our errors are by and large smaller than the average errors were under the old regime.

[At this point Chote produces a chart showing the accuracy of all PSNB forecasts made by the OBR since it was set up, where real figures are now available. The boxes are coded green if the error is below the average error incurred by the Treasury when it was doing these forecasts, yellow if it's in line with the average Treasury error, and red if it's worse than the average Treasury error. There are nine boxes: seven of them are green, one is yellow and one is red.]

But what about growth? If I had asked the people who were raising questions why they thought your forecasts were so bad, I think they would cite growth. Two years ago you were predicting growth of 2%-plus in 2012, and now it's 0.8% and coming down. People look at that and say that shows you're just as useless as the Treasury.

Judging that is harder because the numbers continue to be revised long after you think you know who's done a good forecast and who's done a bad one. That was very clear in 2010. All the forecasts we produced in 2010 under-estimated economic growth in 2010. If you go back even further in time, when I was writing about the economy for the Independent in the early 1990s, in the recession of the 1990s it looked like the economy had shrunk by 4.3% from top to bottom and it had ended in a double dip. That was the story I was writing on the national accounts of 1993. If you now look at the latest official data for exactly the same period, the recession is 40% shallower and there's no double dip.

So do you think if the Treasury had been doing the forecasts in 2010 for 2012, they would have made the same mistake that you made?

If you look at why growth appears to have been weaker in 2011 than we thought – and indeed I think that every one of the independent forecasters polled at the beginning of 2011, no one had anything as weak as 0.7, which is where we've ended up – the main reason for that appears to be the fact that there were pressures on inflation that were higher than people expected. Things like higher oil prices and food prices were squeezing household incomes, squeezing consumer spending.

[At this point Chote produces another chart showing the accuracy of all growth forecasts made by the OBR since it was set up, where the real figures are now available. There are six boxes: three of them are green (ie, better than the average Treasury error), one is yellow (in line with the Treasury average) and two are red (worse than the Treasury average).]

You talk quite a lot about how forecasts are inherently unreliable. In your forecast evaluation report (pdf) last year you said: "The chances of any economic or fiscal forecast being accurate in every dimension are infinitesimally small."

That's certainly true. You cannot just say this is difficult, so there's no point even trying. Governments have to take decisions today that have consequences about what things will look like in one, two, three, four years' time. In order to take those decisions in a sensible way, you have to start with some sort of view about how the world is going to look if you don't do anything or if you do do anything. So it is very difficult, but you still have to do it. The key thing that we're trying to demonstrate in the way we do it is, don't bet the farm on any particular view of the economy turning out to be correct. And it's not enough just to say there's uncertainty around the central view that we've set out. What you need to do is say how much does it matter if we're wrong, and in what sort of ways.

Relations with the Treasury

People have criticised the OBR for being too close to Treasury thinking. When I asked people to suggest questions, Polly Toynbee sent me one on Twitter which was: "Why has the OBR been so wildly optimistic, when Keynesians predicted double dip would be the result of extreme austerity?"

And there's another set of views on the other side of the spectrum. We sit down, we puzzle over the data and the information and we reach the best view that we can, whether the Treasury agrees with that or not. Perhaps to my surprise, and to their credit, they don't come and say "this is our view of the world, you agree, don't you?" holding a large baseball bat up in the air. We all sit and discuss the uncertainties about what is going on. But at the end of the day the great discipline is transparency. We have to show our working. There will always be people who disagree with the view that you express. That's the nature of economics.

Going back to the Treasury, someone on the blog [britannicus] posted this question: "Is it difficult to maintain an independent and objective stance on the government's fiscal performance when you are married to the Treasury's director general responsible for public spending [Sharon White]?"

The short answer is not at all. She's a career civil servant. So she's worked for the previous Labour government, and the Tory government before that. The jobs I've had have involved me being rude about all of them. It has never stopped me in the past and it wouldn't stop me now. Clearly, I felt it was very important when she got that job that we should be transparent about it, so it went straight up on our website when she was appointed and I made sure that the Treasury committee was informed before it happened just so that there weren't any concerns about it.

Allowing the OBR to cost opposition policies

The legislation setting up the OBR says you can't look at the impact of opposition policies. But at some point they're going to review the operation of the OBR. Do you think there's a case for changing the legislation to allow you to cost Ed Balls' policies?

It is certainly something that parliament should come back to in that five-year review. I said when I was appointed that I thought parliament should be very clear with us whether they wanted us to do that or not. I said if parliament did not give a view one way or another, I would talk about the implications of opposition policies.

The Australians are setting up a parliamentary budget office as we speak, which is very much focused at providing the research resources for opposition members to be able to go to this body and say: "I've got a pet plan to change income tax, could you please run the slide-rule over it." If you do that it's quite expensive, because you have to have quite a lot of expertise in quite a lot of different areas.

There's a then even more dramatic example of this in the Netherlands, where every political party in the runup to the election is invited to submit its manifesto to our Dutch equivalent. The Dutch office is multiple times larger than we are, partly because you need to have more resources available to do that.

One of the consequences of this system is that George Osborne will be able to stand up and say to the voters, "here are my budget plans, they've been kitemarked by the OBR", because he's in government. But Ed Balls won't be able to do that. Do you think there's an inherent unfairness in that?

I think it's one of the reasons why it would be a jolly good idea to review this when the five-year thing comes up. When this debate was under way when we were being set up, it wasn't as though the government didn't want that question answered and the opposition did. There was no great push from Labour to say the OBR should have this role, partly, I think, because everybody was concerned that dragging us straight into the debate between plan A and plan B would leave you inevitably as though you were picking sides, and that might be very difficult because the body had only just been set up.

It's entirely reasonable for parliament to want us to establish our credibility and trustworthiness with a narrower mandate before you extend it in that sort of way. I think at the end of the day that having independent rigorous analysis of all the political parties' policies is a good thing for them, it's a good thing for public debate, it's a good thing for democracy.

You could argue that because the IFS does that to a considerable degree there's less need for that here than there would be in some other countries which don't have IFSes. But I think that would still be a positive thing. But it won't happen on my watch.

Are you appointed for …

It's a fixed five-year period. In principle I could do another five after that. I'm allowed to seek a second term if I want to.

But it's not just a question of people saying the OBR should do this. The government at the time would need to be willing to allow HMRC and DWP people to work with us in examining those sorts of things. I think it would be a good thing. And certainly from the point of view of IFS, the fact that we looked at every party's plans, and normally said rude things about all of them, contributed to people's sense of our independence and our evenhandedness. Partly because no party has the monopoly of wisdom or folly, so you normally offending all of them some of the time.

Economic effect of cutting the 50p top rate of tax

Is there any evidence that cutting the 50p top rate of tax will be good for the economy in terms of promoting growth because it will make people work harder, or make people come to the UK to invest?

We didn't think that there was a reason to adjust our medium- or long-term growth forecasts on the basis of that. That was certainly the view that we took back in March.

Is that because the evidence is unobtainable? Or is that because that effect probably doesn't apply?

Well, there's a size issue. When we're thinking about the impact on spending in the economy, we're looking at all the budget measures added together. And if you look at all the measures added together, it was a pretty neutral budget. There were giveaways and there were takeaways. But in most years, and on average over the five years, the takeaways and the giveaways pretty much wash out. So the budget was not doing very much to either inject into or subtract out of the economy additional spending power. The evidence on things like "will this attract particularly innovative people who will have ongoing implications for productivity growth etc", again, you would look at the size of the sums of money involved and at the evidence. Certainly, we didn't feel that there was a strong enough evidence base to say our long-term or medium-term view of the economy is now more optimistic than it was beforehand as a result of that measure, or indeed the other measures.

Sustainability of public sector pensions

Let's turn to public sector pensions. You will have followed the debate about whether or not current public sector pensions are sustainable. What's the OBR view on that?

We last took a view on that debate back in July of last year, which we will update in July this year. The view that we took then was that if you look at the share of GDP that you would be spending on public service pensions – we're talking about pensions for public sector workers, as distinct from the state pension – then that would, on the policies at the time, be falling as a share of GDP rather than increasing. So, looked at in isolation, it's exerting less pressure on the public finances rather than more.

That said, it was part of a broader picture which showed there was an upward pressure on the public finances. So, if you want to deal with the upward pressure in aggregate, you can decide whether to cut the bits that are falling by even more, or whether to try to cut some of the bits that are rising by a bit. It depends on whether you are looking at it in isolation, or whether you are looking at it more widely.

So whether it is sustainable depends on whether you are looking at the public spending cake as a whole, or the public sector pensions bit of it?

Exactly. But that particular slice is not where the problem is coming from, let's put it that way. That's because of linking pensions to CPI inflation, and the fact that you've got fewer public sector workers, implying fewer people you need to pay pensions to in the future.

Tax increases or spending cuts in the long term

You publish a fiscal sustainability report every year. In the last one (pdf), you said the public finances were "likely to come under pressure over the longer term" and that "in the absence of offsetting tax increases or spending cuts this would eventually put public sector net debt on an unsustainable upward trajectory". What does that actually mean in practice?

It's the idea that on unchanged policy the share of national income that you get in tax revenues does not really change very much as you go into the future. The fact that the population is ageing, and there are more people above working age than below working age, doesn't affect the total amount of tax revenue you get in very much, partly because older people are still buying things and they're paying VAT on them. However, if you then look on the spending side, that does rise as a share of GDP on unchanged policy, partly because, as the population ages, you need to spend more on things like the state pension, long-term care, health expenditure. That is where that pressure comes in.

At the end of that report you quote some figures for what tax increases or spending cuts would be necessary as a result of these pressures, depending on what fiscal targets the government set. They're huge figures, £22bn, or £12bn. Do think policymakers have grasped the size of this challenge?

The first thing I would say is that you need to place even more caveats around those sorts of numbers than you would do around shorter-term ones. The value of this sort of thing is painting a general picture of direction.

But the government tries to save a few tens of millions by putting VAT on pasties, and the world goes berserk. And here you are talking about cuts of £22bn.

But you are already seeing, not just this government but previous ones, talking about doing things about pension ages, for example. The debate about whether we ought to systematically link the pension age to life expectancy, that's a debate here.

But do you think the public have woken up to the scale of spending cuts or tax rises that these numbers imply?

It's hard to know with precision. There's been a lot of talk about the implications of an ageing population. I think people are aware of those sorts of pressures. The number of people who would give you a detailed discussion of exactly what per cent of GDP we're talking about I suspect is rather smaller. But I think it is something that people are thinking about and talking about.
